stem: A 62-year-old male with a history of chronic kidney disease (CKD) is admitted with hyperkalemia (K+ 7.0 mEq/L). He reports muscle weakness and nausea. His ECG shows peaked T waves. The physician orders immediate treatment. The nurse should first {{blank1}} and then {{blank2}}.
template: The nurse should first {{blank1}} and then {{blank2}}.

rationale.correct: Calcium gluconate should be administered first to stabilize the cardiac cell membranes and prevent life-threatening arrhythmias caused by hyperkalemia. Sodium polystyrene sulfonate (Kayexalate) is then administered to remove potassium from the body, but it takes time to work. Addressing cardiac stability is the immediate priority.
rationale.incorrect: Administering sodium polystyrene sulfonate (Kayexalate) without first stabilizing the cardiac membrane does not address the immediate risk of arrhythmia. Monitoring urine output alone does not address the immediate hyperkalemia. Initiating dialysis is a longer-term solution and not the immediate action. Administering furosemide may help excrete potassium but is not as effective as calcium gluconate in immediately stabilizing the heart.
clinicalPearls: Hyperkalemia can cause life-threatening arrhythmias; always assess ECG changes.
Calcium gluconate does not lower potassium levels; it only stabilizes cardiac membranes.
Sodium polystyrene sulfonate removes potassium via the GI tract and can cause constipation.

questionTrap.trap: Students often prioritize potassium removal (Kayexalate) over immediate cardiac stabilization (calcium gluconate).
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Remember the ABCs: Airway, Breathing, Circulation. Protect the heart first in hyperkalemia.

mnemonic.title: CBIG K Drop
mnemonic.expansion: Calcium Gluconate, Bicarbonate, Insulin, Glucose - shift K+ into cells; Kayexalate, Diuretics - eliminate K+ from the body.

reviewUnits.title: Hyperkalemia Management
reviewUnits.content: Review the causes, signs, and treatments for hyperkalemia, focusing on immediate vs. long-term interventions.

itemContext.sbar: 17:00, Dr. Smith, this is Nurse Jones on Med-Surg. I'm calling about Robert Miller, a 62-year-old male with CKD, admitted today for hyperkalemia (K+ 7.0). He reports muscle weakness and nausea. ECG shows peaked T waves. He received one dose of furosemide 40 mg IV at 16:00. Urine output is minimal since admission. His creatinine is 5.2 mg/dL and BUN is 60 mg/dL. I'm concerned about potential cardiac complications. I recommend administering calcium gluconate immediately to stabilize his heart and then following with sodium polystyrene sulfonate. Do you agree with this plan, and would you like any additional orders?

tabs.title: Nurses Notes
tabs.content:
15:30: Patient complains of muscle weakness and nausea. Noted peaked T waves on telemetry. Potassium level reported as 7.0 mEq/L. Physician notified.
16:00: Furosemide 40 mg IV administered per order. 
16:30: Patient reports no improvement in symptoms. Urine output minimal since admission. 
17:00: SBAR provided to physician.

tabs.title: Lab Diagnostics
tabs.content: Na 136 mEq/L | K 7.0 mEq/L | Cl 98 mEq/L | HCO3 22 mEq/L | BUN 60 mg/dL | Creatinine 5.2 mg/dL | Glucose 110 mg/dL

tabs.title: Vital Signs
tabs.content: HR 92 bpm, regular | BP 150/90 mmHg | RR 20 breaths/min, unlabored | SpO2 96% on room air | Temp 37.2°C (99.0°F)

tabs.title: MAR
tabs.content: Furosemide 40 mg IV STAT | Metoprolol 25mg PO BID | Insulin Aspart 4 units SubQ AC | Docusate 100 mg PO Daily
